Author: Alright#0419
Content:
```
Upon submission of a proof to the submit-event-proof function, the event is tentatively accepted for a contestation period of k blocks, during which any other party, the contester , can provide a counter-proof showing that the original proof was fraudulent. The contester can call the submit- contesting-proof function passing it the contesting proof œÄ ‚àó and the event predicate e . The function runs the NIPoPoW verify algorithm to compare the original proof events [ e ] . proof against the contesting proof œÄ ‚àó . If the verification algorithm concludes that the original proof was fraudulent, the tentatively accepted event is abandoned and the collateral is paid to the contester
```

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: MoMoM was already implemented before this paper was started it seems. this is a challenge/response method with the assumption that if nobody challenges it, it must be true. sort of a global opt-out system. depending on the number of proofs being submitted, the economic reward available for disproving, maybe there is enough incentive to "mine" for the invalid proofs. It just seems quite complicated to allow all proofs in the system, then remove the ones that are disproven, than to just use MoMoM and keep things clean to begin with.

Author: gcharang#6833
Content:
They are called notary nodes. They are elected once a year by the community. They save kmd's blockhashes to Bitcoin and any assetchain/external chains with dPOW available to KMD chain.
Explanation: https://docs.komodoplatform.com/whitepaper/chapter3.html
Requirements and setup of a notary node: https://docs.komodoplatform.com/notarynode/setup-Komodo-Notary-Node.html
